text: Shannon hi everyone
Anthony van tan oh here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for
your review of the new James Holden
album the inheritors James Holden is an
electronic music producer and DJ as well
as the founder of border community
records an electronic and experimental
music label that has released dozens of
LPS and EPS since it started in 2003 and
essentially James is celebrating the
10-year long life of his label as well
as his much longer career with a new
sophomore album just sophomore album
when it comes to material James is
really more of a prolific remixer he has
quite a few big names under his belt as
far as people whose songs he has
rearranged people like Madonna
Mogwai Four Tet Britney Spears New Order
Depeche Mode Radiohead he's obviously
more of a quality over quantity kind of
guy and if you are a fan who has been
waiting for this new full-length LP you
can't really say he held back in any way
delivering over an hour of music across
15 tracks now like James last
full-length LP this album is beautifully
textured some really rough percussion
pretty somewhat vintage synthesizers
although maybe that vintage flavors
turned up a little bit to the point
where this record reminds me a little
bit of another border community Records
released Luke Abbott's Holcomb drones on
my favorite electronic music LPS of 2010
there's quite a bit of variety on this
LP wah-wah some tracks on here do get a
little tedious even if they are very
colourful songs like the Illuminations
with all of these swirling synthesizer
arpeggios caught within this very aged
recording it feels like a little bit of
Boards of Canada worship it's alright
that Boards of Canada worship actually
continues on other tracks here like
summer spite as well as circle of fifths
while it is very steeped in this
influence what he's doing on these songs
it is kind of noisy it is sharp it is
sort of shrill
and there are other tracks on here that
sort of take a more ambient approach
that lose me a little bit because of how
disconnected they feel from any sort of
real tangible feeling still the more
that I listen to this album and the more
I sort of look at the artwork another
thing that I'm not really crazy about on
this LP there is sort of a theme a
concept that runs throughout most of
this album and for me it kind of starts
with the album cover where we have a
rock carving something that we typically
associate with the idea of primitive
life something that's a rudimentary
but what's actually carved into the rock
if you observe it closely is very clean
it's straight it's not some kind of
crudely drawn Buffalo or anything like
that the symbols on this rock seem
almost as if they're beyond human
comprehension like they're futuristic or
maybe even alien and that's sort of the
dichotomy that this album explores you
have something that feels in a lot of
ways technologically advanced but kind
of has a very old soul to it you've
essentially got a lot of these simple
basic visceral primeval musical ideas
being executed through electronics
through new technology it kind of
reminds me of the balance that was
struck on that Africa hi-tech album that
I enjoyed so much a few years ago except
James approaches it with different
musical influences and styles on the
inheritors James performs a lot of IDM
micro house techno a little bit of
progressive synthesizer an ambient music
and James doesn't really blend all of
these ideas together into cohesive
tracks really he genre hops from song to
song to song like the songs Ranade or
the title track from the cell P which
are really amazingly produced
progressive and riveting techno songs
very noisy dirty rough kind of simple
and they're very linear grooves and each
of these tracks also are colored with
really intense and complex synthesizers
Ranade has these tremolo very fast waves
of sense just pulsating quickly and on
the title track the synths are really
sharp they're blaring there screeching
across the track making it even more hot
and heavy than Ranade that ambient route
comes up again on songs like self
playing schmaltz
or sky burial but some of the chords and
some of the melodies on these tracks
feel really sinister and dark I don't
really feel like I'm listening to
something that is pre civilization like
I think the theme on this album is but
rather post civilization the songs feel
like the the very desolate aftermath of
some kind of great tragedy but maybe the
best tracks on this LP in my opinion are
the ones where we get those primeval and
acoustic instrumentation elements mixed
in with the electronics songs like
caterpillars intervention where the
plucks strings and the blaring
saxophones and the really hard constant
hypnotic again primal beat makes the
song feel like a dance around a campfire
with a drum circle other songs on here
like circle inside a circle the opener
and gone feral as well take these
electronic elements and mix them with
percussion that feels like it was played
with hands or at least just sounds like
sampled hand percussion while it is
electronic it has a very natural kind of
rootsy feel to it in a way and I really
like that I think these tracks are some
of the most unique moments that this
album has to offer
if this album was going to try to go
forward with this theme I would love to
hear more tracks to sort of take it at
this angle because these songs to me are
among the most memorable on this album
but really for me the odd man out on
this LP is the song 7 stars which has
kind of these gothic piano chords and
melodic flourishes throughout the track
it's in 3 4
it's very moody waltz and while it is
very electronic and it is very noisy and
has a nice huge climactic finish I'm not
really seeing where this song fits and
with the rudimentary vibes that I get
from the other melodies and and the
other grooves on this LP rather the song
feels very civilized very refined
overall I did really really enjoy this
LP it had a lot of songs that I enjoyed
it just came down to being a mixed bag
of tracks with a very loose too loose of
a concept really a lot of tracks stuck
out to me as being great very bold
mixtures of old ideas and new sounds
some tracks are really unique pieces of
techno a few are very underwhelming a
few more kind of drown in their
influences but if you're into electronic
music and you
something really textured and you want
something that's colorful and and
something that is above all things just
tense will kind of keep you on the edge
of your seat do give the inheritors a
listen I'm feeling a light a decent
seven on this thing if you've given it a
listen did you love it hate it why what
do you think I should review next and
that's it this review is my opinion if
you don't like it here's a straw I want
to give a shout out to Pyrex Agustin CGT
Esperanza it's a - Billy woods and
Vincent only the strong subscribe all
mistakes were intentional Anthony
Fantana bulette forever
you
